August 28, 1952
Mr. Graydon Ausmus
Vice-President, NAEB
Box 2002
University, Alabama
Dear Graydon:
This Executive Director is becoming quite a
problem.
First, some general observations on the two level
matter:
I think it improbable that we could interest or
afford to pay such a ”top level, high-caliber man with
an established national reputation1’. The government has
a difficult time attracting and holding such men even at
the salary it pays. The type of man you*re talking about
wouldn't look at the job for less than $20,000 a year,
unless he were retired and just wanted to do a job for a
group he believed in.
I think we had better be practical about this. Can
we afford to even think of such a man? It means taking
money from the current operating budget and might mean
mortgaging our future. It is questionable in my mind
whether we would get returns commesurate with what we
would have to pay.
Your second category, it seems to me, is as low as
the first is high. A younger man, yes - but an experienced
educational broadcaster. We can afford to pay enough here
to get a top man. Some have already been mentioned. Bill
Harley, for example. I also feel you would be putting a
good man under a humiliating handicap if there was a lot
of rearranging of the duties and responsibilities of the
Executive Director just because a younger man was coming
in. Somewhat closer supervision for a while, certainly,
but to curtail powers and authority upon such a change
would sap a man's confidence and make undue trouble for
both the Board and Headquarters.
I will not attempt to name anyone In the first
catagory. In the second category, I'm still for Bill
Harley, first and Irving Merrill, second.
Representing non-commercial, educational, radio and television stations, workshops, and production
